entry.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
entry.summary:
The correspondence from the Bitcoin Development Mailing List delves into the intricate possibilities of integrating Post-Quantum (PQ) signature data within the current Bitcoin consensus framework. It suggests that although the present system allows any arbitrary PQ signature to be committed at the time of spending, future modifications could enforce specific values or formats, such as limiting DER signatures to a certain number of bytes. This approach aims to make the system more robust and adaptable to evolving cryptographic standards.
Further discussion highlights the potential for utilizing relative timelocks to incentivize the use of smaller signatures by associating them with lower timelock requirements. This concept introduces a dynamic mechanism to encourage efficiency in signature sizes without compromising security.
The conversation also touches upon the challenges posed by exposed public keys within the network. It is noted that while some public keys are visible, others remain obscured behind hashed outputs like P2PKH. In cases where public keys are not directly known to the network, it suggests the possibility of requiring commitments to specific proofs to enhance security and privacy.
A novel yet speculative solution proposed is the use of "time travel" through the implementation of timelocks on OP_CHECKSIG calls. By deferring consensus on how to migrate funds to a later date, the community can buy time to reach an agreement. The idea posits that continuous extension of these timelocks could eventually lead to a consensus or, alternatively, lead to a situation where the sheer computational power (hashrate) dictates ownership until a more refined solution is agreed upon.
This discussion underscores the ongoing exploration and innovation within the Bitcoin development community to address the challenges presented by quantum computing and other evolving threats. It reflects a commitment to ensuring the long-term viability and security of the network through proactive and creative problem-solving.
